title: PC building help!
body:
Hey guys, basically im in search for a Computer to only play League in a high setting with a high FPS. Not expecting to play on ultra high or anything. Just be able to touch 30-60 FPS and be able to enter teamfights with no lag or stuttering. I need you guys' help to determine which pc build is best for league. Here are the custom pc's that are in the lineup: 

1. Intel, 8GB ram, 700W power, DVD drive, audio, USB, ethernet 1000BT, extra fans, Dell Precision 690 computer with Nvidia 260 GTX, 8 cores, 2 X5355 Xeon CPUs, 500GB hdd, Win 7 Pro

2. .Intel Core i5-660 Processor 3.33-GHz 
.4GB DDR3 RAM 
.250GB Hard Disk Drive 
.DVD-ROM Drive 
.NVIDIA geforce 210 512mb with HDMI output 
.Windows 10 Home 64-Bit 

3. CPU: Intel core 2 quad Q6600 
MOBO: MSI MS-7529 
GPU: Radeon HD 6770 
RAM: Hyperx 2gb ddr2 
Power: Ultra 550w 
CPU Cooler: Ultra Chilltec black 
500gb hdd 
NZXT gamma case

Which would be best and why? 
*if posted in wrong section pls move

replies.body:
Those are some interesting and very different setups you have there! Objectively speaking, they all meet our minimum requirements, but some should perform differently in-game than others, especially when comparing consumer vs production hardware. You may want to reach out to the [**PCPartPicker**](http://pcpartpicker.com/forums/) or [**/r/BuildAPC**](https://www.reddit.com/r/buildapc/) communities for extra insight into this decision.

If you have any other questions, let me know!

Thanks! Ill definitely check them out and see what they got to say but would you be able to say by these stats which would be best for league? I understand they meet requirements though! Thanks again for the quick reply
 Appreciate it

Honestly, I'd have to test them in real matches to verify their performance. Objectively, the last option has the most recent video card, but 2GB of RAM is pretty rough on anything newer than Windows 7. The Q6600 is a rock solid chipset that was a huge hit with gamers for a long time, but it's also aging fairly rapidly at this point. 

There are a lot of things to be said about each computer and their components, which is definitely a big reason why I suggested getting additional input from those awesome communities. :)
I have listened to your advice. Just waiting on replies from them! Thank ou once again
